title.narrative: Homs and Aleppo, Livelihood and Early Recovery for Essential services (HALE)

description.narrative:
Given the improving security context across most of Syria, the increasing numbers of return and the deteriorating economic situation, early recovery is a much-needed sector, especially in areas of high vulnerability. These areas, overlapping with a high rate of returns present little if any basic services for the returning population and extremely limited livelihood opportunities to enable households to return to their former circumstances.
ADRA Syria has selected some of the most vulnerable communities, in line with both ERL and OCHA guidance and will respond to the urgent population needs in early recovery in both rural Homs (Al Qusair) and rural Aleppo (Al Bab, Al Safira, Deir Hafer and Tell Ed-Damman). These areas have been assessed and are considered high severity where services resources and assistance were limited. As a result, immediate response is needed from humanitarian organizations and stakeholders to minimize the suffering of those who have been living in hardship circumstances and to encourage people to return to their areas of origin. The objective of this project is to improve access to essential services and strengthen access to livelihood opportunities resulting in improved community and household level resilience. The HALE projects targets a total of 33,850 individuals (including 9,478 male, 9,478 female, 7,447 boys and 7,447 girls). By focusing on vulnerable households including those with elderly or people with a disability, an estimated number of 2,110 people with disabilities will also directly benefit. As the targeted locations are areas of high return, it is expected that the number of beneficiaries will increase during the life of the project.
Project activities will be conducted through qualified ADRA male and female staff in close coordination with key stakeholders (including the ERL sector, MoSAL, SARC, MoLA and MoE) and include both household level and community level assistance. This will also enhance the mitigation and response to address the needs of boys, girls, people with disability and vulnerable communities. ADRA will include the community and people with disabilities as main key of the project success.
During the couple of months of the project, ADRA will coordinate with local ministries to receive necessary approvals and undertake the technical and vulnerable assessments in the targeted areas, followed by the implementation of the planned activities and monitoring of the project throughout the lifecycle.
